comments.commentBody:
Nick, IV decided there's absolutely no doubt that this midweek MIX of Roman Numerals by Caleb Emmons is to DI for!

Howie TBoQ

When I started working for USDA in 1972 the agency I was employed with for 37 yrs never had a professional level woman.  Not for decades.  Any female was either a secretary or employed by the local conservation district half time or full time.  Paid by a small county tax.  Most were local farmer/rancher wives. I've worked with some conservation district employees, all woman, who were awesome and confident.  Where I live now the district has had as many as 3 full time employees because the county generates enough money.  I think my property tax includes about $4 for the district.  They are the only district in MT that has it's own little cost share program.  The one degreed employee who was paid equivalent of GS-9 just retired after basically doing all the field work for them for 35 yrs.  The NRCS has a whole lot of professional level woman now at all levels.  No one is in a union.

I am thrilled you are heartened.    Were you also heartened when the synagogue  was targeted last year and nothing was done?   Were you also heartened when the police did nothing to protect Jewish children from marauding Arab gangs around Paris?

The insecurity of the Jews of France is well-founded, and residence in Israel offers an attractive alternative. Nonetheless, I am heartened by the muscular response of the French government to protect synagogues and other sensitive Jewis sites in the wake of last week's attack on a kosher synagogue. Bravo to French authorities for protecting France's Jewish community, and to the people of France for their support.

Je suis juif.

Some people just can't take a joke. Threats of physical harm are actionable.

One has to be crazy to analyze insanity rationally. Mass psychosis is not different than interaction among individuals: some insane people who are a potential harm to themselves or others need to be committed to protect society.
The most dangerous idolatry is that which worships an idea.

Was not the "Piss Christ" (under the guise of "art") an intentional act of hate against Christians? Was it not also a "deliberate attack[] meant to inspire outrage . . ."? Where were the non-Christians defending the Christians who were offended and outraged? There weren't any. They were either defending the "Piss Christ" as a work of art or simply laughing at the Christians who were offended."

Or the "Elephant Dung Virgin Mary?" Same thing. Non-Christians found it all amusing.

No religion should receive special, exclusive treatment. We either condemn hate as to all or we don't condemn at all.

Attacks on Mohammed are uniquely attacks on Muslims. They are deliberate attacks meant to inspire outrage, and they do. Attacks that are more general are not attacks specifically on Muslims, so Muslims don't feel specifically attacked.

Most people react badly to being attacked.

Reacting badly is not the same as going on a terrorist killing spree.

We need to focus not on turning the other cheek to calculated attack, but rather focus on acceptable methods to express reacting badly.

Muslims do have it in their power to react in other ways, ways that would be felt, but would not be terrorist with all the blowback that so justly lands on terrorists.

The way to shift the method of expression is to do it, and show it works.

So their leaders ought not be expected to talk Muslims out of being offended when we attack them.

Instead, we ought to hope their leaders will shape their reactions to more acceptable methods, which are also likely to be more effective against those who spread hate and division here.

Perhaps we ought to be defending Muslims from our own attacks on them, showing the way, instead of doing our very best to offend and reacting with surprise when they don't like it.

“He got defined early, after he got through the nomination process, and they spent a lot of money to define him,”
Well, we're looking at the possibility of a Third Bush, why not a Third Iteration of Romney?
Maybe this time his handlers can define him is some literate fashion? Seems unlikely but "hope springs eternal in the human breast".

I disagree with your second paragraphs, and agree with your first and last paragraphs; especially the last one. We should also be looking hard and often at the new congress for indications of whether or not the Republican Party is capable of governing.

To Thomas Hall

Reviewing the early comments, it appears that Republicans fear Hillary running, as they are already descending to mockery instead of reason.
Jeb Bush a good governor? Wow...

Reviewing the early comments, it appears that Democrats fear Jeb running, as they are already descending to mockery instead of reason. However, I'm pretty sure that other Republican candidates fear his candidacy even more!

Mr. Bush was a good governor here in Florida and displayed an ability to see the nuances in political issues--not simply cleaving to ideology. It will be interesting to see if his more nuanced brand of Republicanism can survive the primary process.

Having spoken up in regards to my former governor, I think I'm going to now stop reading "political horse race" stories until, at least, the end of the year. Couldn't we all just ignore the early "analysis" and content ourselves with arguing about the current administration's successes and failures?
I see your point, but I wonder to what extent the people who constitute the base for your generalizations have that much daily access to the web.

Look at the chart again. The internet wasn't around in the early 90s when the drop started, not do you see a change in the drop when it starts to become popular in the late 90s. (The iPhone wasn't released until 2007.)

While the decline in crime started well before another phenomenon having broad social effects as well: Our Virtual Lives. The Internet. More so than television, isn't it something that keeps people indoors? Especially children, who no longer play outside. And even with less crime, fearful parents don't let them roam neighborhoods or playgrounds or woods the way I did as a kid.

Or, rather, Overwork plus the Internet. Television took people off their front porches to be mesmerized before their glowing hearths. But interactive media and connectedness online is potentially more hypnotic, and portable, all at the same time that people are doing the work previously done by 3, 4, 5 people. They come home exhausted. Their devices keep them chained to their jobs. They have no lives, no dinner parties, no evening babysitters, no couples volleyball night at the Y. Some even kill themselves running their kids around to overly structured things, the precious darlings. So they Candy Crush out, instead of raising hell in the local bar. Teenagers are too busy texting to go to malls and hang out. Why circulate outdoors when we can circulate on Facebook without rousting our hinders from our soft chairs?

Who has time to be out and about thinking of crimes to commit in these exhausted days where most of us don't really move much, unless to hunter/gather a non-home-cooked, diabetes-inducing meal, except perhaps meth-heads for whom time and brain waves move at a different speed?

In New Jersey we have many real life fictional characters. Usually they are unnamed mid level civil servants responsible for the loss of 100's of millions of dollars that would otherwise be directly attributable to the Christie Administration. In almost refreshing to hear about a real life fictional character who is just asking questions and not losing millions for the state.

“But the wisest words came from an 82-year-old woman in Florida,” he said. “She grabbed my hand and asked me a simple, but powerful question: ‘What’s happened to our country? We used to control events. Now events control us.’”

First of all who speaks like that? What event, a wedding, a black Friday sale?

That 82 year old woman is actually about 2 days old, born from the mind of a speechwriter. After watching Veep on HBO I just can't listen to any of this spin cycle nonsense. I fear the reality is much too close to the comedy. Produce that 82 year old and I will vote for you. That's what I thought...
The ability to raise money is almost but not quite all in politics, particularly Republican politics. The "not quite" part is important. Christie will fall.
Romney did the same in Massachusetts.
He'll never stop slobbering. Remember his slobbering before Sheldon Adelson?
This Calvinist descendant of Dutch, French and Scottish Calvinists has no problem with that. The cream always rises to the top.

In responding to a previous article about Jeb Bush I had occasion to look up the word patrician in the Online Dictionary. I was delighted to find that the dictionary used Papa Bush as the example of what a patrician was.
Why do we use words like liberal and conservative when we are really talking about oligarchs, fascists and those who believe in democracy. Jeb Bush is not a conservative he is an old time aristocrat who believes that the best society is one where he and his ilk rule and the rest of us serve.
The Deists who wrote the Constitution were in fact Unitarians and were well versed in the works of John Milton. John Milton the liberal Puritan is largely credited with founding Unitarianism, America was founded on the principle that "It is better to serve in Heaven than rule in Hell." The Bush family are descendants of that branch of Conservative Puritans steeped in the Calvinist principle of it is their duty to rule.
The words liberal and conservative mean little when applied to a patrician whose political tendencies span the millenia of human societies.
A patrician is a patrician is a patrician and liberal and conservative are not modifiers.

The 90 million who are unemployed but don't count as unemployed, the people who disagree with Jonathon Gruber as to their intelligence, the people who didn't get to keep their insurance or doctor and the people it is claimed have a new job but at much lower wages may disagree with you.

Conservatives do what they always do: they try to optimize the present, the future be damned.

5 of the last 6 US Presidential popular elections went to Democrats. In the electoral college, the Democratic nominee needs just one or two states to win an election above those states that vote blue regularly.

You can write dozens of articles about the next possible Republican nominee, but the next Democratic nominee will likely be the next US President.
Dole, McCain, Romney.....and now Jeb Bush.  If the Republican Party presidential process was a movie it would be called "Death Wish 4....Night of the Living Dull."

We have a Representative Republic. To the founders Democracy was mob rule. Allowing the people direct control would lead to chaos as brilliant rhetoricians sway the mob with appeals to emotions instead of deliberative logic. While we do elect our representatives to government they do not always follow the desires of the electorate precisely because the making of laws requires consideration of the effects of law. Mobs tend to want something and want it now regardless of the consequences.

Another possible Bush problem: his belief that "We live in a democracy". I don't fully understand it, but the Tea Party insists that we live in a republic, not a democracy. My guess is that this means that in a republic those in charge listen to the choices of the voters, except when those choices disagree with Tea Party dogma, in which case they can ignore those choices of the voters.
It's hard to see Bush winning the Republican nomination without at least guarded support from white supremacists and xenophobes.

Shoo-in. It means easily done.

Not shoe-in, which means having to force one's way in.
Well, what have we learned?  Apparently, not much.  Bush is a shoein.

To a biolgist, this looks exactly like a speciation event. It is classic Darwinian evolution. Usually, this pattern is seen when two "niches" allow individuals to isolate into groups, and these groups then evlolve along separate trajectories. The political parallel I suppose would require two nations in the end.

His own mother has said, in effect, that the American people shouldn't vote for him. Need I say more?

But I will: - :)

I don't think Jeb or Hilary will win the presidency. There is someone out there who will cut right through the "valley" in the center of graph #2 and ride on to victory. Don't know who but I bet there are at least 10 people capable of doing just that.

Can you imagine how much fun it would be to get to campaign against Jeb (and his feckless brother) on one side and Hilary (and Bill the glutton) on the other?

BRING IT ON !!!
Oh, a monster, really?  Smaller government, lower taxes, abiding by the Constitution......such scary stuff.

can jeb defeat the tea party? who cares? republicans created this monster i hope they are it's victims over and over again. why on earth would we care if they can "defeat" the monster?
this seems eerily familiar to a mel brooks movie..... "no matter what i say? do not open this door".

Jeb Bush not highly conservative?  Mr. Edsall, you of the chattering class got it wrong in 2000, when after Jeb Bush disenfranchised enough "suspected felons" in Florida to give his brother that state (hardly a centrist deed), you said that W's biggest problem would be to rein in his right wing.  Instead, of course, he led Cheney's charge rightward.  Maybe the Bushes fooled you once in 2000, so shame on them.  But if you swallow this line again, shame on you (even though W famously was unable to recall this saying).
Not another Clinton either, please! Please! Please! Please!
Not another Bush, please!
Lots of terrorism in the news since he started running. I wonder if he will make it the centerpiece of his campaign.

Dear mags and all who are tempted to not vote:  When you withhold YOUR vote your give extra weight to the other side.  This is why state Republicans won in 2010 and then went on to gerrymander districts to disempower Democratic voters and to pass voter ID laws to eliminate additional Democratic voters.  It is how this nation can get a President elected by a minority of a minority and one who represents the 1%.  This is how democracy slides into oligarchy and oligarchy into kleptocracy.  Don't vote and you empower those who are picking your pocket by eliminating your jobs and their tax contribution.  Not voting is like shooting yourself in the foot and thinking your can win the race.
Bush is a loser. I will not vote for another Bush or Clinton. Ive had enough of their stuff.
At least they opened up the articles for commentary. I'm hoping Huckabee can win the GOP nod. He's a decent, core values American, pro-growth, and tough as nails when it comes to security.
That would be nice.

What am I missing about this guy?  Every other day now the Times publishes another puff piece about Jeb Bush, giving him invaluable credibility and publicity.  Is this the prelude to an endorsement of him in the primaries and general election?
